ns0:coredata.dc:title: Revisiting ‘Sabil’ buildings as nuclei of sustainable urban mobility in Fatimid Cairo: An urban-touristic approach considering urban and environmental qualities

Adel Elsayed, Marwa
Salaheldin Ismail Elsayed, Doaa
ns0:coredata.dc:description: This study adopts two levels of comparative urban analysis to investigate the current role played by Sabil buildings as nuclei for sustainable urban rehabilitation in Al-Muiz Street, Fatimid Cairo, Egypt. The study is tackled from an urban touristic approach to promote linear and diffused mobility. Hence, Linear Urban Mobility Analysis divided the linear spine into nine sectors based on Sabil locations. These varied in densities, activities, services, social behaviour and opportunities. They were compared based on a matrix including quantitative and qualitative parameters reflecting the existing urban conditions, and were added to an ArcGIS ModelBuilder to develop a spatial assessment model. Then, for a Diffused Urban Mobility Analysis, three proposed itineraries were compared using validated software programs to scrutinise their urban and environmental qualities. The results present a pilot study for promoting sustainable urban mobility in historic cities based on Sabil buildings contextual settings.

Environmental quality
Historic Cairo
Sabil buildings
Sustainable urban rehabilitation

ns6:head.ns7:title: Revisiting ‘Sabil’ buildings as nuclei of sustainable urban mobility in Fatimid Cairo: An urban-touristic approach considering urban and environmental qualities
ns6:head.ns7:short-title: Revisiting ‘Sabil’ buildings as nuclei of sustainable urban mobility in Fatimid Cairo

ns7:affiliation.ns7:label: a
ns7:affiliation.ns7:textfn: The British University in Egypt (BUE), Faculty of Engineering, Architectural Engineering Department, El Sherouk City, Egypt
ns7:affiliation.ns7:source-text: The British University in Egypt (BUE), Faculty of Engineering, Architectural Engineering Department, El Sherouk City, Egypt

ns7:affiliation.ns7:label: b
ns7:affiliation.ns7:textfn: Kafrelsheikh University, Faculty of Engineering, Department of Architecture, Kafrelsheikh City, Egypt
ns7:affiliation.ns7:source-text: Kafrelsheikh University, Faculty of Engineering, Department of Architecture, Kafrelsheikh City, Egypt

ns7:abstract-sec.ns7:simple-para: This study adopts two levels of comparative urban analysis to investigate the current role played by Sabil buildings as nuclei for sustainable urban rehabilitation in Al-Muiz Street, Fatimid Cairo, Egypt. The study is tackled from an urban touristic approach to promote linear and diffused mobility. Hence, Linear Urban Mobility Analysis divided the linear spine into nine sectors based on Sabil locations. These varied in densities, activities, services, social behaviour and opportunities. They were compared based on a matrix including quantitative and qualitative parameters reflecting the existing urban conditions, and were added to an ArcGIS ModelBuilder to develop a spatial assessment model. Then, for a Diffused Urban Mobility Analysis, three proposed itineraries were compared using validated software programs to scrutinise their urban and environmental qualities. The results present a pilot study for promoting sustainable urban mobility in historic cities based on Sabil buildings contextual settings.

ns7:section.ns7:para: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) designated the historic Cairo area as a World Heritage Site in 1979, hence, conservation and rehabilitation plans were assigned to regenerate the historic centre and ameliorate the living conditions of its local community [1]. The latest was the United Nations development program (UNDP) initiative, which proposed a rehabilitation plan for historic Cairo in 1997 [2]. The plan focused on Al-Muiz Street; being the major spine extending north–south the Fatimid capital, of rich architectural, cultural and social potentials. The UNDP dedicated this touristic route for pedestrian use only; aiming to achieve a car-free historic centre [3].

Sabil buildings are significant landmarks along the urban spine, which is a term for historic charitable water storage outlets that played a vital role in providing order and measure to the organic urban fabric [4]. It is a significant building typology of particular architectural as well as urban influences upon the Medival Cairo [5,6]. Cairo once had over three hundred Sabil buildings and they were vital elements in various neighbourhoods acting as landmarks with significant morphological characters within the compact city fabric [7,8]. The setting of Sabil buildings determined the extent of walkability limits for users, which ranged between 100 and 150 m [4]. In this sense, they played a similar role to that of the school in the modern planning approach for residential neighbourhoods [9]. Al-Muizz Street has a unique cultural ensemble of diversified typologies of Sabil buildings through different periods. Nevertheless, the authors argue that the UNDP rehabilitation plan disregarded the role played by Sabil buildings in the urban fabric and paid less attention to the rich network of cultural heritage buildings and urban spaces located beyond the touristic route.

A number of previous studies promoted the application of sustainable forms of mobilization for historic areas [10–12]. Several approaches and lessons pointed out their urban qualities [13,14] to support local businesses [15] and maximize the urban experience [16]. Furthermore, other scholars pointed out the importance of considering the environmental aspects as well [17,18]. This can be divided into linear and diffused pedestrian mobility approaches [14,19]. Hence, the authors suggest that revisiting Sabil buildings as nuclei of urban units from an urban touristic point of view would promote different spatial rules transforming the walkability experience through the cultural landscape. Thus, historic spines could be perceived as space intervals varying from one Sabil to the other, representing different urban and cultural features. Accordingly, the role played by Sabil buildings in this sense can be understood as a framework guiding, measuring and controlling the regenerated urban unit.

Al-Muiz street holds within its fabric more than 9 Sabil buildings located along the 1500 m long spine. Hence, the study adopted a dual-tier analytical study to promote sustainable urban mobility of pedestrian itineraries in historic cities. This includes a) Linear urban mobility analysis (LUMA); studying the entire urban spine in terms of a set of qualitative and quantitative parameters. Then, the study developed an assessment matrix assessing and documenting the main defined sectors. These parameters were added as a database to the ArcGIS 10.7 to develop a spatial assessment model. The model included 12 quantitative parameters for proportions of urban sectors, facades, flooring, street furniture, land-use suitability, the density of activities, public amenities, public open spaces, visual extrusion, availability of vacant land and dilapidated buildings as well as walking distance and time. It also included 9 qualitative parameters for the clear accessibility to Sabil buildings, connectivity with other sectors, preservation of traditional businesses and crafts, potentials of public involvement, urban safety, the presence of cultural diversity, creative mobility, the effect of informal activities and finally the legibility of historical events. A latter step of a Dispersed Urban mobility analysis (DUMA) focused on a single urban sector defined based on the location between two Sabil buildings as shown in Fig. 1 . This presented an interconnected urban spine of heritage Sabil buildings in Fatimid Cairo with identified layers of interrelations. The result contributes to significant transformations in sustainable rehabilitation planning. This would eventually develop new perceptions of sustainable pedestrian urban mobility considering urban and environmental qualities. The present research is intended to support decision-makers, heritage conservationists and experts to develop sustainable urban rehabilitation integrated approaches for heritage conservation and protection and support the touristic industry for Fatimid Cairo.

This section includes a dense literature review for international scientific journals in the last 10 years for sustainable urban mobility, frameworks, models and criteria guiding the rehabilitation of cultural landscape and urban heritage.

Historic quarters in contemporary cities are perceived through mobility and flows as much as sedentary places. Since the 1980 s, more cities assigned pedestrian itineraries as the dominant mobility in historic quarters [17]. Previous studies have promoted the application of sustainable forms of mobilization for historic areas [10–12]. Also, several approaches and lessons were discussed for the benefits of promoting sustainable forms of urban mobility [13,14]. This shall enable the mutual interrelation between cultural and physical landscape to coexist allowing the diversified historical layers to harmonise with the inherited social activities [9,20]. It shall also guide people’s experience of space through a hierarchical system providing urban safety and social collectively. Furthermore, it may help internally displaced persons living near areas with cultural heritage values to regain their social identity [21] and help develop a touristic wayfinding route. This is in addition to its role in facilitating the legibility of hidden historical events. Further, sustainable urban design and planning aim at making use of clean and renewable energy sources at early design stages. In this regard, generations of city planning consider sustainable forms of urban mobility [22]. This is in addition to attempts for sustainable renovation for existing built environment [23,24] and some approaches for applying smart building materials and techniques in transportation hubs [25].

ns7:section.ns7:section-title: Reviewing assessment parameters for sustainable urban mobility
ns7:section.ns7:para: Setting sustainable rehabilitation plans based on promoting pedestrian mobility in historic cities involves a number of steps. This requires defining the assessment parameters, determine the tool used to assess each parameter, analysis and presenting results [23,26]. A recent study investigated available assessment and benchmarking tools with particular attention to green building rating systems. The study showed a lack of proper tools for sustainable rehabilitation practices [27]. Furthermore, a number of indicators and models were applied to assess the impact of pedestrianization and walkability in historic cities [19,28,29]. Graphical means were also applied to map walkability potentials based on a ‘Transient oriented approach’ as a sort of assessment for the quality of the urban environment [30]. The assessment parameters indicated in previous studies is shown in Table 1 .

ns7:section.ns7:section-title: Reviewing available tools and methods for sustainable urban and environmental analysis
ns7:section.ns7:para: Applying sustainable urban rehabilitation calls for using advanced tools and methods to provide a comprehensive understanding of a range of complex sustainable aspects and support the decision-making process therein. One study used game theory to discuss space allocation and dynamic interaction of world heritage landscapes to achieve the three bottom-line objectives for sustainable maintenance and organization practices [43]. Another study used parametric and associative three-dimensional modelling automation to investigate inaccessible monuments in heritage buildings [44]. Other studies investigated energy efficiency upgrades during the renovation process e.g. improving the thermal envelope, energy installations and systems and employing renewable energy systems [45,46]. Other studies concerning Fatimid Cairo recommended the application of heritage building information modelling [47]. Also, numerical modelling was applied to evaluate the outdoor microclimatic conditions [18].

A previous study modelled the visual performance of a residential area showing that its unique visual characteristics originated from the collective perception of its architectural components within their urban context [48]. A following study investigated the effect of daylighting strategies to preserve the identity of the Cairene context taking the rehabilitation of the area of Darb El-Asfar in Fatimid Cairo [49]. The results pinpointed the necessity of accounting for daylight levels and reflections to maintain visual perception. In this regard, performance and prescriptive guidelines should be considered [50]. Also, parametric design and analysis tools are other promising software programs to perform urban and environmental analysis e.g. temperature, humidity, solar radiation…etc. [51].

The most significant characteristic of the urban fabric of historic Cairo is its organic and irregular pattern that was generated according to levels of privacy and social needs [52]. Accordingly, the number of deviation points reflects the authenticity of the urban fabric revealing how far it maintains its culture within the urban morphology [53,54]. Hence, visibility analysis is useful to determine what can be seen by an observer from a given location. This can be done through site visits and photography and most commonly through computer programs. In this regard, the Isovist and viewshed analysis are used to investigate the area in a spatial environment directlyvisiblefrom a location within the space [53]. The former is used to compute an isovist sampling at a certain location. It enables studying the visible urban fabric within a sequence of test points along each path [54,55]. The latter uses a computer algorithm to define a viewshed or the region that can be seen from a specific position. To determine the visibility from a certain cell or observation, the analysis sets the elevation value of each cell from a digital elevation model. It is commonly used to determine the view from a road [53,56,57].
This type of analysis investigates the environmental quality of a building or space. For this study, it shall be limited to include the following:

Carbon emissions: there are many models proposed to measure carbon emissions [13,58,59]. This is determined based on the scope of measurement, life cycle stage and tools used e.g. accounting for operational and/or embodied carbon [60,61]. One commonly used type of tool includes the carbon footprint calculators which are mainly used for calculating domestic carbon footprints and operational carbon emissions as a result of energy usage during building occupation [62,63]. Other types of tools include carbon estimators and calculators used for estimating embodied carbon emissions in a building based on the operational stage [60,64].

Microclimatic conditions: many previous studies focused on outdoor thermal comfort as a result of microclimatic conditions [65–68]. It is a very important aspect especially in hot and dry climates [69,70]. This includes factors related to air temperature, humidity, wind speed and solar irradiation [71] and is very much dependent on the urban geometry, vertical street profile and building materials [66,69]. This uses instantaneous and continuous measurement [66] as well as simulation programs. Also, the solar radiation analysis enabled calculating the direct solar radiation falling on an input geometry using a selected sky matrix in a specific analysis period. Noting that the range of acceptable solar irradiation is currently 1360 W m−2 and it increases by a scale of 1 astronomical unit for an increase of each 200 W/m2 [72,73].

In this regard, the Rhino-grasshopper is one of the most extensively utilised platforms among designers nowadays. It integrates standard EnergyPlus Weather files (EPW) and generates a variety of 2D and 3D designer-friendly interactive visualisations to aid decision-making for both urban and environmental analysis. It also streamlines the analytical process, automates and speeds up calculations, and gives simple graphical displays [74].

It is also noted that the Geographic Information System (GIS) is used for many types of urban and environmental spatial analysis [75]. It was used to map carbon emissions [76] and along with spatial regression, a spatial model was developed to promote walkability [77]. In this regard, the ArcGIS ModelBuilder constructs and executes simple workflows and designed queries that combine a set of geoprocessing tools that feed both output and input data. It is also considered a visual programming language used for constructing and executing both simple and advanced extended ArcGIS models. It can also be integrated with other applications for different analytical purposes e.g. Python script [78].

This section reviewed previous studies to identify existing gaps and limitations. It indicated the lack of present studies discussing the network of urban interrelations and mobilization particularly for project types with cultural values such as the Sabil buildings. These carry a physical, environmental, cultural and social impact on urban planning and can direct an evolutionary approach to sustainable urban rehabilitation.

The research method was divided into two subsequent levels as shown in Fig. 2 ; LUMA which studied the entire linear spine of Al-Muizz Street and characterized nine urban sectors according to the distance from one Sabil building to the other. This was followed by DUMA for the defined sector. This provides a comprehensive perspective for sustainable pedestrian mobility in historic cities Fig. 3.T.
Fig. 4.T. .
This phase investigated the Sabil role to promote linear mobility.

The study started with a series of site visits identifying the current state of the historical urban spine of Al-Muiz Street in the Al-Gamaliya district of 1 km long and area of 720,000 m2. This step used a set of qualitative and quantitative measures deducted from the literature review. Then, the information was compiled into a geospatial database using the ArcGIS ModelBuilder for the spatial location of Sabil buildings and surrounding areas. Accordingly, Sabil buildings were taken as repetitive nuclei of similar urban units of the same type. This defined nine sectors (varying in densities, activities, services, social behaviour and opportunities) related to the distance from one Sabil building to the other. The compilation of these parameters established overlapping, query and GIS model expressions to document and assesses the nine different sectors. The model reflected the existing urban conditions along the linear mobility spine; informal activities and deteriorated urban facades, pollution, erosion and visual distractions. The sectors were divided as follows:
•
Sector 1: The Gateway to Sabil-Kuttab Sulayman Agha Al-Silahdar
•
Sector 2: Sabil-Kuttab Sulayman Agha Al-Silahdar to Sabil-Kuttab Katkhudha
•
Sector 3: Sabil-Kuttab Katkhudha to Sabil-Kuttab Mohamed Ali Al - Nahaseen
•
Sector 4: Sabil-Kuttab Mohamed Ali Al - Nahaseen to Sabil-Kuttab Khusru Pasha
•
Sector 5: Sabil-Kuttab Khusru Pasha to Sabil-Kuttab Shaykh Ali AlMutahhar
•
Sector 6: Sabil-Kuttab Shaykh Ali AlMutahhar to Sabil Ashraf Barsbay
•
Sector 7: Sabil Ashraf Barsbay to Sabil-Kuttab Al Ghuri
•
Sector 8: Sabil-Kuttab Al Ghuri to Sabil-Kuttab Mohamed Ali in Al Aqqadin
•
Sector 9: Sabil-Kuttab Mohamed Ali in Al Aqqadin to Sabil-Kuttab Nafisa-AlBayda

Further analyses were carried to investigate the type of economic activities, their intensity and identify potentials of open spaces and vacant land plots along the spine as shown in Figure 3.T which were seen as potentials to develop and enhance the walkability experience along the street and promote diffused pedestrian itinerates (as shall be discussed in phase 2).

A set of quantitative and qualitative parameters were defined based on previous literature [12,17,48] to enable the assessment process for the role played by Sabil building as nuclei of urban units as shown in Table 2 . These parameters were ranked from 1 to 3 based on survey local occupants’ perception through sub-structured interviews carried in December 2019. This includes:

−12 Quantitative parameters for the proportions of urban sectors, facades, flooring, street furniture, land-use suitability, the density of activities, public amenities, public open spaces, visual extrusion, availability of vacant land and dilapidated buildings as well as walking distance and time.

− 9 Qualitative parameters for the clear accessibility to Sabil buildings, connectivity with other sectors, preservation of traditional businesses and crafts, potentials of public involvement, urban Safety, the presence of cultural diversity, creative mobility, the effect of informal activities and finally the legibility of historical events.

These qualitative/quantitative parameters were used to develop an ArcGIS model using GIS 10.7 ModelBuilder as shown in Figure 4.T. Hence, spatial analytical techniques were used for two main reasons; a) verify that the Sabil building was used as repetitive nuclei of similar urban units of the same type along Al-Muizz Street, b) document, populate and integrate qualitative and quantitative parameters to assess the nine sectors in relation to the role played by Sabil building to promote linear mobility.

The ArcGIS ModelBuilder was used to assess the defined sectors using geoprocessing tools, datasets, map layers and other data types (e.g. shapefiles, raster maps…etc.). The model organized the parametric database systematically and logically into a number of feature classes. These represented the current urban condition for the study area according to the predefined parameters. This was followed by data population and integration pointing out the potentials of linear urban mobility and connectivity based on Sabil buildings as a nucleus of urban units. It provided advanced methods of analysis in sequential strings of geoprocessing tools; feeding the output of one tool as input for the other. Running the designed model iteratively allows selecting the optimized section according to the aforementioned assessment criteria.

Three models were designed and structured based on the assessment parameters defined in the previous step. This queries the database to select the optimum sector. It performed data filtering to obtain different results according to the potentials of each sector. This showed the difference between the defined urban sectors and enabled comparing them to show the optimum sector. The first model indicated the sectors with the highest obtained criteria (Good ranking). The second model showed the sectors with the medium criteria (Medium ranking) and the latter model showed the sectors with the least obtained criteria (Poor ranking).

This level of analysis discusses the Sabil role to promote dispersed mobility. It focuses on an urban sector of area 17,200 m2, perimeter = 103 m, as shown in Fig. 5 . This links point 1 ‘Khisro Sabil’, point 2 ‘Khatkhoda Sabil’ located in Al-Muiz Street to point 3 ‘Beet Elqadi’ square. The selection was based on the optimum sector determined in the previous step, taking its 2 defined sabil buildings defining its beginning and its end. The third point represents a dispersed hidden context to that sector.

ns7:section.ns7:section-title: Defining the urban sector and proposed itineraries
ns7:section.ns7:para: The following three itineraries were pinpointed to link the three defined points; A, B and C. This defines the optimum urban linear and dispersed routes for an urban upgrade.
The spatial analysis was categorized for this study into urban and environmental analysis.

The urban analysis was used to compare the visual exposure to the cultural heritage buildings. Hence, parametric analytical tools (ladybug-grasshopper) were used to study urban visibility and exposure through the isovist field analysis and view analysis.

For the isovist field analysis, the extent of the visibility radius was set at 500 m. The study achieved the isovist field analysis over a grid of 320mx260m, which reflected the study area of Al-muiz Street and its surroundings. The test points were inserted according to the deviation points along the path as follows; Route A: 5 test points, Route B: 7 test points and Route C: 2 test points. This was decided based on the number of deviation points along the route which affected the visibility of cultural heritage buildings.

The Ladybug view analysis was used to evaluate the visibility of an input geometry from a set of key viewing points. It was used for evaluating and calculating the average percentage of the test geometry seen by the test viewpoints. The study selected a test geometry composed of the hidden cultural heritage buildings existing beyond or adjacent to Al-Muiz Street but not clearly visible (these were 15 buildings). The key viewing points were inserted on the 3D Rhino model to reflect visual points along each path. The study set a grid size of 5 m which represented the average size of the grid cell for visibility analysis on the test geometry. A distance from the base was set to 0.01 m, representing the offset distance of the test point grid from the input test geometry. An average of 5 to 7 view test points was defined along each path. Accordingly, the study investigated the average percentage of visibility to the hidden cultural heritage buildings in relation to each path in order to select the path of the highest average views.

The environmental analysis was used to compare the environmental quality of the three itineraries as shown in Fig. 6 . Hence, the outdoor solar radiation analysis was performed using parametric analytical tools (ladybug-grasshopper), noting that other measures such as air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction had an equal effect for the three itineraries in this scale of analysis, this is due to their proximity as stated by [71]. Another study was carried to compare the estimated carbon emissions for each route.

The solar radiation analysis enabled calculating the direct solar radiation falling on an input geometry using a selected sky matrix in a specific analysis period. This analysis was carried for the purpose of the study for the summer period, from June till September because it represents the peak summer season and the most concern for researchers in Egypt [81,82]. The selected test geometries represented street surfaces where the surrounding buildings were designed as the sunlight blocking geometries. A grid size of 3x3 m was set to perform solar radiation analysis on the tested surface with an offset test point distance of 0.01 m from the input test geometry and compare the results.

For the carbon emission analysis, site visits and observations were carried to determine the average number of means of transportation for each route; noting that private cars were not allowed. Hence, Route A = 50 motorcycles, Route B = 50 motorcycles, and Route C = 100 motorcycles, 56 shuttle buses and 112 vans. Then a calculation model was performed to account only for the vehicles not the buildings nor the other sources model was used to compute the carbon emissions generated in each route based on its length and the existing means of transportation crossing it on an annual basis according to [83]. This was determined based on multiplying the route length by the sum of emissions produced by different means of transportations crossing the route on an annual basis. For this study, operational carbon emissions were considered based on the fuel used for each vehicle.

The result of site visits, observations and questionnaires among local occupants indicated that Sabil buildings marked the dominance of certain business activities practised along the spine. The 9th and 8th sectors were dominated by textile and clothes commercial activities, while the 7th and 6th sectors inhabited indigenous activities of perfumes and spices. The 5th sector was occupied with jewellery businesses and crafts, but the 4th, 3rd and 2nd sectors were based on metal crafts and coffee shops. Finally, the 1st sector was dominated by markets and domestic activities. Furthermore, it was noted that the intensity of deteriorated urban conditions increased with the escalated intensity of activities in each sector; which was significant for the 9th, 8th, 7th and 6th sectors. On the other hand, the physical condition and social behaviours developed with the decrease of activity intensity, which was noted for the 5th, 4th, 3rd and 2nd sectors. Moreover, the study showed the availability of open spaces in the 1st, 2nd, 3rd and 4th sectors more than the 5th, 6th, 7th, 8th and 9th sectors, which directly affected the urban condition of these sectors and pinpointed potentials of urban upgrade.

The GIS analytical techniques verified that the Sabil building was used as repetitive nuclei of similar urban units of the same type along Al-Muizz Street. The spatial analysis showed that the dimensions from one Sabil building to the other marked 9 urban sectors with a distance ranging from 100 to 170 m each. Only the interval distance of the 8th sector extending from Sabil-Kuttab Al Ghuri to Sabil-Kuttab Mohamed Ali reached 262 m. In this case and following the fact that Sabil Sulyman bek Alkharbotly and Sabil Zein Al Abedin were located in nearby alleys to Al-Muizz street, the concept of the urban unit of the Sabil building was still fulfilled but in a more diffused context rather than a linear one. Though the 6th sector extending from Sabil-Kuttab Shaykh Ali AlMutahhar to Sabil Ashraf Barsbay was only 68 m, nevertheless, this could be justified due to its small scale and the fact that it was a complementary element in the complex of the school and mosque of Al-Ashraf Barsbay. Hence, Sabil Shaykh Ali Al-Mutahhar that was built 319 years later was an essential structure to fulfil the area’s need for drinkable water. The result presented an interconnected network of Sabil buildings along Al-Muizz Street perceived through 9 urban sectors. This indicated that this governing urban mobility planning regulation can be revisited for resilient contemporary rehabilitation practices in Fatimid Cairo.

Then, the model was used to pinpoint the optimum urban sector which considered the role of the Sabil buildings as urban units. This sector exhibits the optimum qualitative and quantitative parameters to promote Linear urban mobility flows according to Table 3 . Hence, the optimum urban sectors can be arranged as follows;
•
Sector 3: Sabil-Kuttab Katkhudha to Sabil-Kuttab Mohamed Ali Al – Nahaseen
•
Sector 4: Sabil-Kuttab Mohamed Ali Al-Nahaseen to Sabil-Kuttab Khusru
•
Sector 2: Sabil-Kuttab Sulayman Agha Al-Silahdar to Sabil-Kuttab Katkhudha
The results of the spatial studies are presented as follows;

Comparing the solar radiation analysis for the three itineraries showed that route A achieved a balance of favourable intensity of solar radiation that achieves outdoor thermal comfort. The results of the isovist analysis indicated the following areas for each route. Route A: 5 test points and isovist area of 4426 m2, Route B: 7 test points and isovist area of 3961 m2 and Route C: 2 test points and isovist area of 5071 m2. The average percentage of visibility was calculated using the view analysis as follows: Route A = 2.20%, Route B = 0.77% and Route C = 1.64%. Hence, it can be concluded that route A achieved the highest average view percentage to the hidden cultural heritage buildings- existing beyond Al-Muiz Street. The result of comparing the three itineraries in terms of carbon emissions showed that Route A had the least share of carbon emissions, followed by itineraries B and C, of 0.39, 0.42 and 5.76 tons/year, respectively. Hence, comparing the three itineraries according to the predefined assessment criteria shown in Fig. 7 showed that route A was the optimum route in terms of solar radiation analysis, least carbon emissions and providing views and exposure to the urban context but its performance was lower in terms of Isovist field analysis. This pinpoints potentials to promote dispersed urban mobility connecting Sabil buildings using this route.

The scope of this study did not look at the historical background of each Sabil building but looked at them equally based on their contextual setting. This is different from other studies which discussed Sabil buildings in isolation from their urban context. The area of interest was limited to Al Muiz street only, hence, the selection of parameters was based on the historical, socioeconomic and cultural status therein. This pilot study can be applied to other contexts characterized by Sabil buildings. It may also be replicated to include other significant elements of historic cities to investigate how they promote linear and diffused mobility within their surrounding urban context. This can be seen in other countries as well e.g. Wind mills [84], Aqueducts [85,86], Wind towers [87,88]…etc.

The research method was designed to address each level of pedestrian mobility with different spatial analysis. This showed an integration of advanced tools for urban and environmental analysis e.g. survey, spatial analysis and model expression as well as parametric design and optimization techniques.

The LUMA, was defined based on the 21 parameters previously deducted from the literature review. They were all ranked from 1 to 3 based on surveying local inhabitants, and given equal weighting in the model. Furthermore, the DUMA investigated factors associated with the microclimate. These were limited to solar radiation, view analysis, carbon emissions, noting that the list is not exhaustive but may include other parameters depending on the peculiarities of each project.

The limitations of some research tools should also be considered. Hence, it is noted that the ArcGIS ModelBuilder input data was based on the selected parameters. These used vector data only and the query was based on survey responses for the state of each parameter. Using this pilot model in other databases necessitates matching the field names, which maybe problematic without a standard terms of reference for ArcGIS. Also, the model used a variety of data sources e.g. shapefiles, hard copy maps, hence, this required a process of synchronizing data into one format to enable performing the analysis. Also, there is no standard visual representation for the results of the ArcGIS ModelBuilder. Furthermore, the Isovist analysis depended on the number of deviation points, while the accuracy of the viewshed analysis depended on the resolution needed and requires a following step to interpret to quantitative values.

There is a current debate for means of applying sustainable rehabilitation scenarios in historic cities. This does not mean looking at cultural heritage buildings and urban fabric in isolation, but more importantly at their intrinsic interrelationship which can be perceived by mobility and flows. Hence, pedestrian itineraries can be promoted through linear and dispersed mobility in the urban fabric. Sabil buildings can play a main role in this regard. This requires further investigation for its physical role as a landmark and regulating urban unit, preserving environmental concerns in planning and promoting socio-economic and cultural activities. This qualifies its role to be revisited as nuclei for sustainable urban rehabilitation. Hence, this study presented referral points to guide further rehabilitation actions in a cross comparative dual-tier analytical study.

This discussed Al-Muiz Street in Fatimid Cairo on a linear urban mobility analysis aiming to pinpoint the optimum sector where the role of Sabil buildings was pronounced. This analysis was based on the 21 parameters previously deducted from the literature review. These included 12 quantitative parameters to account for factors associated with the physical urban setting (e.g. proportions of urban sectors, facades, flooring and street furniture), considerations of urban design (public open spaces, land-use suitability, availability of vacant land and dilapidated buildings), users’ experience in space (visual extrusion, as well as walking distance and time). This is in addition to socioeconomic activities (the density of activities and public amenities). It also included 9 qualitative parameters for the users’ experience in space (clear accessibility to Sabil buildings, connectivity with other sectors, urban safety and creative mobility), social activities (potentials of public involvement), economic activities (the effect of informal activities) as well as cultural considerations (preservation of traditional businesses and crafts, the legibility of historical events and the presence of cultural diversity). Then it was further elaborated to discuss its role in promoting dispersed mobility in sub-routes. This promotes urban continuity and connectivity, considers microclimatic conditions and visual perception and explores cultural heritage buildings existing beyond the touristic route.

Hence, this multidimensional investigative study pinpoints the need for a further update to our theoretical researches and professional practices that would influence future rehabilitation plans in historical cities. The role of Sabil buildings and similar historical landmarks should be revisited in modern rehabilitation approaches. In this study, their role was investigated to promote both linear and dispersed mobility in Fatimid Cairo. Applying this integrative thinking shall eventually create an interconnected network of Sabil buildings in a cohesive urban fabric.Hence, defining urban sectors should follow proper proportions that mark the walking distance and time between every two successive stops. It should include rich urban features of facades, flooring and street furniture that recognise the dimension of the urban unit in terms of patterns/colours, enhance the visual connection and connectivity of Sabil buildings network. Land-use suitability is another concern to add creative cultural activities transforming the authentic function of Sabil buildings to contemporary time.

This is considered as a pilot study to investigate the capacity of historic Cairo to act as a sustainable historic quarter of better urban and environmental qualities and less carbon emissions. This novel contribution can be replicated for similar urban contexts aiming to promote the urban and environmental performances of historic urban centres and eventually expand beyond the nine clusters proposed by the UNDP.

ns7:section.ns7:label: Appendix
ns7:section.ns7:para: Do you think that presence of Sabil Buildings enhances the sense of continuity?
Do you think that the urban context surrounds the Sabil Buildings need renewal?
What safe activates do you prefer to perform in the place?
What type of facades is present around Sabil Buildings?
What do you most remember from the activities that surround Sabil buildings?
Do you move freely or do you find the surrounding activities are dense enough to obstruct the pedestrian movement?
Do think the urban context encourages the economic activities to develop more?
To what extent do you find the service area of Sabil buildings?
Which proportional ratio of the street to the building do you find?
To what extent do you find the condition of surrounding facades?
To what extent do you find the condition of street flooring?
To what extent do you find the street furniture sufficient?
To what extent do you find the surrounding activities to Sabil buildings homogenous or not?
To what extent do you find the dense of commercial activities?
To what extent the Public Amenities are available?
To what extent do you find the open spaces are accessible to the Sabil buildings?
To what extent the height of the surrounding buildings affects the visual perception of the Sabil Buildings?
How many vacant lands are available and can host future development?
How long do you walk to move from Sabil to another?
How much time do you spend moving from one Sabil to another?
To what extent do you find the accessibility to the sabil buildings is there Clear?
To what extent are the different urban sectors connected?
To what extent is The preservation of the intangible heritage embodied in traditional crafts and businesses?
To what extent does the open space have the potentials to host social and public events?
To what extent do the dense activities affect the user’s safety?
To what extent Does the socio-cultural hybridity present?
To what extent do you consider the availability of creative mobility?
To what extent do you find the intensity of visual and physical informal activities disturb the surrounding urban environment?
To what extent Do you find the quality of historical events comprehensible to you?
